title: How to Spy on Your Competitors
description: To beat your competitors, you'll need to know their marketing activities. We'll show you how to view and track this valuable information.
content: Chris Haines Chris is an SEO director who has 10 years of experience in SEO, agency side. When not involved in SEO, he enjoys messing around with vintage synthesizers, walks on sandy beaches, and a good cup of tea. But how exactly can you view and track their activities?Itâ€™s simpleâ€”you can use a tool like Ahrefs to find out.Contents1. Spy on your competitorâ€™s marketing activityNot sure who your competitors are? Plug a domain into Ahrefsâ€™ Site Explorer and go to the Organic competitors report. Sidenote. Iâ€™ve selected â€œDonâ€™t compareâ€ to keep the visuals simple, but you can compare dates if you wish.In this example, we can see Grammarly outperforms everyone, both on organic traffic and organic traffic value. Letâ€™s spy on its overall marketing activity to see what makes its strategy so powerful.Scroll down to the Top competing domains report to see Grammarlyâ€™s marketing activity metrics.When it comes to DR (Domain Rating), traffic, value, and share, Grammarly is way ahead of the competition. It also has a lot of pages. Clicking on the downward-facing caret by the domain name gives us access to a powerful menu where we can learn more.This menu allows us to see the:Total organic and paid keywords.Backlink profile.Top-performing content.History of its site on Archive.org. Overview of its marketing performance in Site Explorer.This is often the best place to start spying, as you get an overview of its organic and paid marketing activity in a single menu. If you see anything that catches your eye, you can click from this menu to dig deeper into the details.TIPIf you had multiple competitors, you could use the â€œTop competing domainsâ€ list to quickly analyze their performance.Having established that Grammarly ranks for a lot of organic keywords, we can now look at what they are in more detail.2. Spy on your competitorâ€™s organic keywordsWe can use Ahrefs to spy on the organic keywords for any website.If we enter Grammarlyâ€™s website into Site Explorer and head over to the Organic keywords report, we can see the keywords its website ranks for.Hereâ€™s what I look at when spying on a competitor while using this report:I check the KD column â€“ How hard are these keywords to rank for? How much effort will I need to put in to surpass my competitor?I check the â€œtrafficâ€ column â€“ How much organic traffic are these keywords driving on your competitorâ€™s site? Whatâ€™s the prize?From this analysis, itâ€™s possible to determine whether targeting these keywords is worth your time. In more simple terms, itâ€™s an effort-to-reward ratio analysis.The chart below shows Traffic Potential (TP) plotted against Keyword Difficulty (KD). Here, we want to look for keywords that fall in the top left of the chart. The key point here is that effective organic search marketing needs to be targeted. Otherwise, you will just be hoping that something sticks.3. Spy on your competitorâ€™s organic traffic and rankingsThere are two main ways to spy on your competitorâ€™s website traffic and rankings:Using Ahrefsâ€™ Site Explorer â€“ Best for quick checks.Using Ahrefsâ€™ Rank Tracker â€“ Best for long-term monitoring of activity.Tracking a competitorâ€™s organic traffic in Site Explorer is as simple as entering the domain name and clicking search. We can then see the â€œOrganic searchâ€ keywords and traffic in the Overview report. If we go to its traffic (click on the 23.2M number), it will take us to the Top pages report. From here, we can see our competitorâ€™s rankings at the bottom of the page.TipIf you want more long-term tracking on multiple keywords, you can also use Ahrefsâ€™ Rank Tracker.You can track keyword wins and losses for any website by using the Calendar feature.Hereâ€™s what it looks like:Clicking on the calendar on a specific day shows you the wins and losses for the websiteâ€™s keywords for that particular day.Letâ€™s say we only want to view the keywords that have improved in position. We can do this by going to the checkboxes in the bottom left-hand corner and deselecting everything apart from â€œImproved.â€We can now see significant improvements in keyword positions on February 22â€“27. We can click on a day on the calendar to check the keywords that improved positions. Iâ€™ve selected February 22, 2023.Scrolling down the page, we can see that the top keyword improvement was for the keyword â€œthank you.â€Although weâ€™ve seen how this feature can be used to show keyword improvements, you can also use it to identify keyword losses of your competitors.Letâ€™s repeat the process, but this time look at the lost keywords by only selecting the â€œLostâ€ checkbox.We can see that this site lost more than its average number of links in early March 2023. 4. Spy on your competitorâ€™s website and page valueKnowing the amount of traffic a website gets and the keywords it ranks for is important. But most businesses will want to see the dollar value of their competitorsâ€™ websites.To find this out, plug a competitorâ€™s domain into Ahrefsâ€™ Site Explorer, and youâ€™ll see the value in the â€œOrganic searchâ€ summary.In this example, the estimated value of Grammarlyâ€™s organic search traffic is $5.1M.To find the value of a specific page on a competitorâ€™s website, you can use Ahrefsâ€™ Site Explorer. Letâ€™s plug grammarly.com into the search bar and head over to the Top pages report.Then add a URL filter containing /blog/. This will enable us to find the most valuable blog pages on Grammarlyâ€™s website. You can use any URL filter you like. But as most websites have a blog, this is often a good place to start.5. Spy on your competitorâ€™s Google adsWhen it comes to paid advertising, you can use Ahrefs to monitor your competitorâ€™s Pay Per Click (PPC) activity on Google.Hereâ€™s how.Enter your competitorâ€™s domain into Ahrefsâ€™ Site Explorer and hit search.This website has been bidding on ~7K keywords, driving around ~799K in paid traffic. This is an excellent overview, but what if we want more detail?Scrolling down the page, we can see the history of the paid traffic in a chart.This example shows that a lot of paid activity was switched off after December 2022. Also, we can see that the 2023 activity is much lower than that of early 2021.To see the relationship between PPC and SEO, we can overlay its â€œPaid trafficâ€ with its â€œOrganic trafficâ€ like this:The chart shows that when organic traffic does well, the paid traffic is reduced.We can click on the Ads report if we want to see the type of ads that this site is running.From there, we get a detailed breakdown of its paid activity and ads detail.If I want to filter all of Grammarlyâ€™s ads containing the keyword â€œplagiarism,â€ I can do this quickly by adding a description containing a filter with this keyword.Once you have added the â€œContainsâ€ filter, hit â€œApply.â€Youâ€™ll then see Grammarlyâ€™s ads that contain this keyword. This can be a great way to spy on your competitorsâ€™ descriptions on their Google ads.6. Spy on your competitorâ€™s authors Identifying the authors writing a websiteâ€™s content is an underutilized spying strategy, in my opinion. Hereâ€™s whyâ€”with this data, you can:Understand which authors are driving the most traffic to a website and identify their top-performing articles.Understand the value of the traffic each author is driving to the website. Recruit top authors from other websites, understanding their business value even before you see their resumes.See how many articles authors have written, the length of their content, its social shares, and the type of topics they are writing about.Letâ€™s head to Ahrefsâ€™ Content Explorer, plug in site:grammarly.com, and click on the â€œAuthorsâ€ tab.If we scroll down, we can see 72 authors on this website.Looking at the top author, we can see that he drives considerable traffic to the site through only 42 pages. The traffic value of these pages is $285.5K.If you work with a PR or outreach team, you can use this feature to identify journalists to work with quickly and easily.Another way to use this feature is to search for mentions of your competitor using Content Explorer but exclude your competitorâ€™s website.To do this with Grammarly, we would enter the following into the search box:"grammarly.com" -coupons -promo -codes -site:grammarly.comSidenote. The code above tells us to look for mentions of grammarly.com online. But it excludes Grammarlyâ€™s website and mentions of keywords that include coupons, promo, or codes. I excluded these to filter for blog articles about my competitor.From this, we can see that 14,113 pages mention Grammarly excluding these keywords. If we click on the â€œAuthorsâ€ tab again, we can see who has written the articles.As we can see from the list, some authors are from high-authority sites. We can approach these journalists and pitch to them.7. Spy on your competitorâ€™s links If a competitor has a higher DR than your website, itâ€™s usually a good indication that you can benefit from analyzing their links to determine what links you need to get.To find what links your competitor (or any website) has, simply plug the domain name into Ahrefsâ€™ Site Explorer and head over to the Referring domains report.We can see that Grammarly has some high DR links. If your business wants to recreate some of these links, we can start by looking for publications in the list.Iâ€™ve noticed that the Guardianâ€™s website is linking to Grammarly. Using Site Explorer, we can click on â€œLinks to targetâ€ and see the exact links from the Guardian.We can see in this example that the Guardian has referred to the Oxford comma article on Grammarlyâ€™s website.If we right-click, copy this URL, and paste it into Content Explorerâ€™s search bar, we can find the author and other helpful information on this page. We can even discover the authorâ€™s social media profile on this screen.Clicking on the authorâ€™s name takes you directly to their Twitter profile. From there, you can pitch why they should link to your website. Sidenote. In this article, weâ€™ve looked at Grammarly as an example of a top-performing competitor website. To learn more about Grammarlyâ€™s SEO strategy, you can check out Joshua Hardwickâ€™s article on Grammarlyâ€™s SEO.Weâ€™ve established that this method is an excellent way to find high-DR link prospects. But what if you want to discover many opportunities in one go?To do this, you can use the Link Intersect tool. It allows you to compare your website against the competition.To get started, plug in your competitors in the top rows and add your website in the bottom row.In this example, you can see a list of the links your competitor has, but your website doesnâ€™t. Iâ€™ve used some made-up website examples here, but you get the idea.In summary, this is a great way to spy on your competitor and use that information to find new link prospects. Final thoughtsSpying on your competitors gives you insights you wouldnâ€™t get anywhere else. It gives you a barometer of whatâ€™s working in your industry and encourages you to up your game.Using tools like Ahrefs makes keeping tabs on your competitors easy, allowing you to stay at least one step (or position) ahead of them in Google.
